Back to Franz Liszt

Franz Liszt

Années de pèlerinage, Première année (Suisse), S. 160

1848–1854 · LW A159 · R. 10a

[Wikipedia] · [IMSLP]

Total duration: 49' 30"

  • 1. Chapelle de Guillaume Tell
  • 2. Au lac de Wallenstadt
  • 3. Pastorale
  • 4. Au bord d’une source
  • 5. Orage
  • 6. Vallée d’Obermann
  • 7. Eglogue
  • 8. La mal du pays (Heimweh)
  • 9. Les Cloches de Genève (Nocturne)

Album d’un voyageur (S. 156; A40a–c; R. 8) was composed between 1834 and 1838, published in 1842, and comprises three parts: Impressions et poésies (I), Fleurs mélodiques des Alpes (II) and Paraphrases (III). The third part had earlier been published separately under the title Trois Airs suisses (LW A27a).

Between 1848 and 1854, Liszt revised a selection of pieces from the first two parts of Album d’un voyageur to form the bulk of Années de pèlerinage, Première année (Suisse) (S. 160; LW A159; R. 10a). He added two new pieces to these revisions: Orage, which was newly written, and Eglogue, whose origins are contemporaneous with Album d’un voyageur.

In 1876, Liszt revised the third part of Album d’un voyageur as Trois Morceaux suisses (S. 156a; LW A27b; R. 8).

The below table gives a summary of the relationships between the works.

Recommended editions

  • New Liszt Edition (Editio Musica Budapest) · I/6 · Z. A/B 7474 · Années de Pèlerinage I · ed. Imre Mező / Imre Sulyok [including later ending for no. 4 (S. 160/4bis)]
  • Henle · HN 1490 · ed. Peter Jost [including later ending for no. 4 (S. 160/4bis)]
  • Peters · EP 72782 · ed. Leslie Howard

1. Chapelle de Guillaume Tell

This re-uses a theme from the lost Grand Solo caractéristique à propos d’une chansonnette de Panseron (S. 153a; LW Q3).

Duration: 6' 30"

Difficulty: 3.5

2. Au lac de Wallenstadt

Alongside the versions used in Album d’un voyageur and Années de pèlerinage, Première année (Suisse), this piece exists in an intermediate, manuscript version from 1839 (S. 156/2a bis). The three versions have only minor differences.

Duration: 3' 30"

Difficulty: 3

3. Pastorale

Duration: 1' 30"

Difficulty: 3

4. Au bord d’une source

For Giovanni Sgambati in 1863, as an alternative to the final two bars of this piece, Liszt wrote a different, nine-bar ending (S. 160/4bis).

Duration: 4'

Difficulty: 4.5

5. Orage

Duration: 4' 30"

Difficulty: 4.5

6. Vallée d’Obermann

In around 1880, based on an initial arrangement by Eduard Lassen, Liszt made an arrangement of this piece for piano trio (S. 378a–c; LW D18) that he titled Tristia.

Duration: 13' 30"

Difficulty: 4

7. Eglogue

Duration: 3' 30"

Difficulty: 3

8. La mal du pays (Heimweh)

In this revision of a piece from Album d’un voyageur, Liszt also includes a theme from the Fantaisie romantique sur deux mélodies suisses (S. 157; LW A21; R. 9).

Duration: 6'

Difficulty: 3

9. Les Cloches de Genève (Nocturne)

Duration: 6' 30"

Difficulty: 3.5
